nodes.text: Firms exist and have the classical contractual structure because team production, information costs, and monitoring incentives make organizing resources within a firm more efficient than organizing solely by market exchanges
Team production is a class of production where multiple inputs produce a nonseparable joint output so individual marginal products are hard to observe and apportion

The firm is a contractual response: a central party (residual claimant/monitor) common to all input contracts reduces monitoring costs and shirking by holding rights to observe, reassign, and receive the residual
The relative costs of metering productivity across markets versus within an organization determine whether cooperation is organized via markets or via firms
When monitoring is costly, individual input owners have incentives to shirk because private realizable costs of shirking are less than social costs, causing lower team productivity
Formal definition and method: team production is nonseparable production where cross partial derivatives are nonzero and output cannot be expressed as a sum of separable individual outputs

Granting a monitor residual claimant rights plus unilateral rights to alter membership and contracts concentrates incentives to monitor and discipline team members and thereby economizes on metering costs
Profit-sharing arrangements reduce shirking incentives among small teams but become less effective as team size increases because each member bears a smaller share of losses from shirking
Different organizational forms (partnerships, corporations, mutuals, socialist firms, unions) arise as responses to varying information and monitoring cost structures and political constraints

Corporate features (transferable shares, delegated decision authority, salability) and market for control (proxy battles, block purchases) are institutional responses to delegated-manager monitoring problems

Owners of firms tend to hold resalable durable capital (machines, land, buildings) because such assets commit wealth that credibly supports promises to hired inputs and are easier to pledge than human wealth

The firm functions as a specialized private market that collects, collates, and sells information about heterogeneous inputs, enabling cheaper discovery of superior input recombinations than external market search

Conclusion: the classical firm is characterized by joint input production, multiple input owners, a common contractual party who holds residual claims and unilateral renegotiation rights, and the right to sell that status
Assumption: nonpecuniary preferences (leisure) enter utility and detection/monitoring costs are positive, which generate incentives to shirk and motivate organizational responses

Prediction/Result: political constraints or enforced residual sharing (e.g., socialist firms) or nonprofit ownership increase manager shirking risk and induce complementary control devices such as worker committees or other monitoring arrangements

Claim: firm size and divisionalization reflect a trade-off between costs of collating wider input information internally and attenuation of monitor control; larger scope increases information collation costs and may induce divisions
